doc.title: Investor Sentiment: Risk-Love
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Investor Sentiment Risk-Love First signs of euphoriaInvestor Sentiment Risk-Love First signs of euphoria_2025-08-29

passages.text: Global Risk- Love, our contrarian sentiment indicator, has risen to the \(93^{\mathrm{rd}}\) percentile of history since 1987. The euphoria - underpinned by low cash level, volatilities, spreads, and put- call ratio - is not confirmed by other measures of sentiment, namely the B & B Indicator and the Sell- Side Indicator, as well as the technicals, and positioning components of Risk- Love. The elevated sentiment should serve as a sign for investors to stay vigilant. However, it does not call for a change in the constructive stance as earnings, policy, and market breadth remain squarely in favor.

Sentiment is spread out from buoyancy in Hong Kong, Singapore, and South Africa, to neutral in Japan, Taiwan, and Malaysia, to panic in Indonesia. China Risk- Love edged higher to the \(65^{\mathrm{th}}\) percentile as investors find comfort in the nation's AI breakthroughs, confidence in policy measures, and an extension in US- China trade truce. India Risk- Love slipped but still away from the panic zone, as the country braces for fallout from punitive tariffs on goods exports. Surprisingly, Korea Risk- Love, despite a remarkable \(42\%\) rally YTD, is far away from any signs of euphoria. AI cycle, potential policy reforms under the new leadership, and enhanced collaboration with the US post the trade deal are fueling the current rally. Investor sentiment for Poland, Mexico, Brazil, Chile, and the Philippines has begun to recede from peak euphoric levels observed in recent months.
Euphoria in HK, Singapore, and South Africa, to neutral in Japan, Taiwan, and Malaysia, to panic in Indonesia
Current value relative to history
Source: BofA Predictive Analytics
BofA GLOBAL RESEARCH

Exhibit 5: Risk-Love Indicator (Equity sentiment) Summary: today vis- a- vis history On a scale of - 100 (most pessimistic/bullish signal) to +100 (most euphoric/ bearish signal), our Risk- Love Indicator shows the following - Global: 93, Japan: 40, Emerging Markets: 35, Asia ex- Japan: 41, China: 65, India: 25, Taiwan: 42, Korea: 26, Hong Kong: 90, Singapore: 96, Indonesia: 7, Malaysia: 41, Thailand: 20, Philippines: 73, South Africa: 93, Poland: 76, Turkiye: 81, Brazil: 61, Mexico: 65, and Chile: 82
Current value relative to history
Source: BofA Predictive Analytics

Global Equity Risk- Love Exhibit 6 shows our global equity Risk- Love indicator. As shown in Exhibit 7, this indicator tracks positioning, put- call ratios, investor surveys, price technicals and volatility, spreads, and correlations measures (see glossary for further details).
Exhibit 6: Global Equity Risk-Love close to hitting euphoric levels after the Panic levels witnessed in April Global Risk-Love is at the \(93^{\text{rd}}\) percentile of its history since 1987
Source: BofA Predictive Analytics, Bloomberg
Global Risk-Love inputs can be broadly divided into five categories - positioning/flows, put-call ratios, investor surveys, technicals, and volatility/spreads/correlations)

1 Broker optimism - Consensus stock rating for MSCI EM universe (W)  
2 MSCI Emerging Markets ETF premium/discount to NAV (D)  
3 Asia ex- Japan fund cash holdings (M)  
4 Investors' exposure to EMs - Global Fund Manager Survey - asset allocation (M)  
5 Investors' exposure to China - Global Fund Manager Survey - asset allocation (M)  
6 Commitment of commercial traders - S&P 500 Index futures longs to shorts (D)

7 Put / call ratio at market open (ISE Sentiment Index) (D)  
8 CBOE put/call ratio (D)  
9 Euro Stoxx 50 put/call ratio (D)  
10 Nikkei put/call volume ratio (D)  
11 MSCI Emerging Markets ETF put/call volume ratio (D)  
12 S&P 500 options put/call skew (delta 25, 3 month) (D)

13 American Association of Individual Investors - bull less bearish ratio (W)  
14 National Association of Active Investment Managers Exposure index (W)  
15 Small retail trader sentiment (Daily sentiment index) for S&P 500 (D)  
16 Major professional brokerage firms and advisors sentiment (Consensus Bullish Sentiment Index) (W)  
17 Emerging markets economic surprises Index (D)  
18 University of Michigan Survey of Consumer Confidence Sentiment (M)  
19 Commodity sentiment (Daily Sentiment index) (D)

20 Emerging markets cyclicals/defensives (3m change) (D)  
21 Emerging market turnover, % MSCI market cap (D)  
22 MSCI Emerging Markets - distance from 200D moving average (D)

23 CBOE S&P500 VIX Index (D)  
24 Eurozone volatility index VSTOXX (D)  
25 CBOE Emerging Markets ETF volatility index (D)  
26 Nikkei volatility index (D)  
27 SPDR S&P 500 ETF short interest ratio  
28 Hong Kong short interest, % total turnover (D)  
29 Asia Pac ex- Japan stock-to-stock correlations (M)  
30 EM stock less bond returns (6m change) (D)  
31 BofA option volatility estimate (MOVE) index (bond volatility) (D)  
32 Global FX volatility index (D)  
33 Asia ex- Japan CDS spread (D)  
34 US 2Y swap spread (D)  
35 BAA spread (Moody's corporate bond yields less US 10Y govt bond yield) (D)

Source: BofA Predictive Analytics, LSEG Data & Analytics, Bloomberg, CEIC, FactSet, BofA Asia Pac Quantitative Strategy, Trade Futures, Consensus Inc. See Appendix for details. Note: D denotes daily data, W denotes weekly data and M denotes monthly data.

Our Global Equity Risk- Love indicator components heatmap above indicates the following changes today versus last month for the underlying constituents (on a scale of - 100 (most pessimistic/bullish signal) to +100 (most euphoric/beardless signal):

1. Broker optimism - Consensus stock rating for MSCI EM universe moved from 87 to 71  
2. MSCI Emerging Markets ETF premium/discount to NAV moved from 47 to 28  
3. Asia ex-Japan fund cash holdings moved from 87 to 94  
4. Investors' exposure to EMs - Global Fund Manager Survey - asset allocation moved from 51 to 78  
5. Investors' exposure to China - Global Fund Manager Survey - asset allocation moved from 8 to 69  
6. Commitment of commercial traders - S&P 500 Index futures longs to shorts remain unchanged at 13

7. Put / call ratio at market open (ISE Sentiment Index) moved from 93 to 88  
8. CBOE put/call ratio moved from 82 to 87  
9. Euro Stoxx 50 put/call ratio moved from 10 to 9  
10. Nikkei put/call volume ratio moved from 18 to 16  
11. MSCI Emerging Markets ETF put/call volume ratio moved from 48 to 96  
12. S&P 500 options put/call skew (delta 25, 3 month) moved from 57 to 54

13. American Association of Individual Investors - bull less bearish ratio moved from 37 to 15  
14. National Association of Active Investment Managers Exposure index moved from 73 to 95  
15. Small retail trader sentiment (Daily sentiment index) for S&P 500 moved from 78 to 70  
16. Major professional brokerage firms and advisors' sentiment moved from 59 to 78  
17. Emerging markets economic surprises Index moved from 64 to 34  
18. University of Michigan Survey of Consumer Confidence Sentiment moved from 6 to 3  
19. Commodity sentiment (Daily Sentiment index) moved from 79 to 62

20. Emerging markets cyclicals/defensives (3m change) moved from 80 to 51  
21. Emerging market turnover, % MSCI market cap moved from 57 to 65  
22. MSCI Emerging Markets - distance from 200D moving average remain unchanged at 76

23. CBOE S&P500 VIX Index moved from 68 to 64  
24. Eurozone volatility index VSTOXX moved from 69 to 75  
25. CBOE Emerging Markets ETF volatility index moved from 91 to 92  
26. Nikkei volatility index moved from 51 to 39  
27. SPDR S&P 500 ETF short interest ratio moved from 82 to 74  
28. Hong Kong short interest, % total turnover remain unchanged at 100  
29. Asia Pac ex-Japan stock-to-stock correlations moved from 31 to 88  
30. EM stock less bond returns (6m change) moved from 82 to 86  
31. BofA option volatility estimate (MOVE) index (bond volatility) moved from 64 to 70  
32. Global FX volatility index moved from 86 to 80  
33. Asia ex-Japan CDS spread moved from 86 to 59  
34. US 2Y swap spread moved from 99 to 100  
35. BAA spread (Moody's corporate bond yields less US 10Y govt bond yield) moved from 78 to 81
Overall, the Global Risk-Love indicator moved from \(84^{\text{th}}\) to \(93^{\text{th}}\) percentile of its history in last one month.

Risk- Love is a contrary investor sentiment indicator. It tries to quantify investor emotions and helps us understand swings in investor psychology based on data on positioning, investor surveys, volatility, spreads, correlations, hedging and market technicals measures. We have constructed Risk- Love indicators for major Asian / emerging markets as well as for the world as a whole. When at extremes, the indicator is valuable in anticipating reversals in investor mindset, and thus markets.

The Global Risk- Love indicator has 35 factors. It signals buy when it is low and sell when it is extremely high. See Investor Sentiment: Risk- Love: The brain, bulls and bears 08 July 2015 for more information.
1. Commitment of traders - S&P 500 Index futures: longs to shorts Measures open interest for all traded S&P500 commercial futures, broken down into long and short positions.
Market cap-weighted consensus (IBES) stock rating for the MSCI EM universe.
3. MSCI Emerging Markets ETF premium/discount to NAV The difference between the closing price of the fund/ETF and that day's NAV.
The fund- weighted average of percentage of cash relative to total asset held by active funds that have dedicated geographic exposure to Asia ex- Japan.
Based on the BofA Global Fund Manager Survey, this measures the net percentage of global asset allocators saying they are overweight Emerging Market equities.
Based on the BofA Global Fund Manager Survey, this measures the net percentage of global asset allocators saying they would overweight China equities.

The Put/Call ratio shows put option volume relative to call option volume. Sentiment is deemed excessively bearish when the ratio is at relatively high levels, and excessively bullish when at relatively low levels.
Indicators used include the following:

1. Put/Call ratio at market open (ISE Sentiment Index)  
2. CBOE Put/Call ratio  
3. Euro Stoxx 50 put/call ratio  
4. Nikkei put/call volume ratio  
5. MSCI Emerging Markets ETF put/call volume ratio  
6. S&P 500 options put/call skew (delta 25, 3-month)

This ratio reflects the sentiment of individual investors towards the stock market over the next six months - either bullishness or bearishness in the stock market. The question asked is "I feel that the direction of the stock market over the next six months will be". High bullish readings in the poll usually are signs of market tops; lows ones, market bottoms.

The index represents the average exposure to US equity markets reported by members of the Association of Active Investment Managers. It provides insight into the actual adjustments active risk managers have made to client accounts over the past two weeks.

This is a contrary opinion indicator. High \(\%\) bullish readings suggest that a short- term top is developing or has been made. Low \(\%\) bullish readings suggest that a short- term bottom is developing or has been made.

A gauge of positions and attitudes of major professional brokers and advisors, which provides an indication of potential market directions. When a predominant number of market analysts are bearish, it is quite likely that the market is approaching an oversold condition, and that a reversal in trend may be forthcoming.

The Citi Economic Surprise Index measure data surprises relative to market expectations. A positive reading means that data releases have been stronger than expected and a negative reading means that data releases have been worse than expected.
This Index is comprised of measures of attitudes toward personal finances, general business conditions, and market conditions or prices.

This is a contrary opinion indicator. High \(\%\) bullish readings suggest that a short- term top is developing or has been made. Low \(\%\) bullish readings suggest that a short- term bottom is developing or has been made.

The 3- month change in the MSCI EM cyclicals/defensives index, where cyclicals comprise energy, materials, consumer discretionary and industrials sectors and defensives comprise consumer staples, healthcare, utilities and telecom sectors.
Turnover of MSCI Emerging markets as a percentage of MSCI market cap.
The higher the index is from its 200- day moving average, the more bullish the market is becoming.
Measures the implied volatility of options on the underlying index or ETF. Lower readings indicate complacency in the market and higher readings represent greater uncertainty/fear.

1. CBOE S&P500 VIX Index  
2. Eurozone volatility index VSTOXX  
3. CBOE Emerging Markets ETF volatility index  
4. Nikkei stock average volatility index  
5. Hong Kong short interest, % total turnover  Hong Kong Main Board short selling turnover value as a percentage of total turnover

This is calculated as the 3- month rolling stock- to- stock correlation of daily price returns of all the stocks in the region. The lower the correlation, the higher the opportunities for investors to add alpha from stock selection.
Calculated as the difference between 6- month total returns of the MSCI EM index and BofA Global EM sovereign and credit index.
This is a yield curve weighted index of the normalized implied volatility on 1- month Treasury options.
Market cap- weighted CDS spread of 8 Asia ex- Japan markets.
The spread between the rate on a two- year interest- rate swap and U.S. Treasury yields.
This is calculated as Moody's corporate (BAA) bond yield less the US 10Y government bond yield.
